page.title: 07Moorland and Heath
page.content: Moorland rising from 500 feet above sea-level to as much as 1300 feet at King's Tor, covers nearly all the area other than the immediate Walkham valley, and is controlled by the Dartmoor National Park. The upper slopes have granite outcrops surrounded by boulders and clitter. The larger rocks, known as Tors, have names such as Vixen Tor. Its shape resembles an Egyptian Sphinx, particularly if viewed from the Tavistock-Merrivale road. The rock piles of Pew Tor are imposing, offering a fine view of moorland to one side, cultivated country to another and the distant Tamar estuary to another. Close to Heckwood Tor is a large worked stone originally intended for Plymouth Breakwater but rejected on account of a flaw.
